The updates outline procedures for the gradual closure of educational institutions in the case of confirmed Covid-19 infections, which will follow the guidelines issued by local emergency and crises committees and teams in each emirate.  "Such procedures include closing the educational establishment for three days, if the infection rate exceeds 15 per cent of the total attendance," Wam said.  Those who come into contact with Covid-19 positive cases are no longer required to quarantine, while following the guidelines issued by health authorities.  Those infected with Covid-19 or who have respiratory diseases may opt for the option of distance learning.  The Ministry of Education and NCEMA said that all the updates are applicable nationwide. They added that their implementation will be carried out in co-ordination with each emirate's emergency, crises and disasters committees.  https://archive.ph/cUBRc

Most shops, restaurants, tourist attractions and religious establishments across the UAE are open but there are restrictions and requirements in place to help contain the spread of COVID-19. With effect from 26 February the rules for mask wearing have changed and although mask wearing remains mandatory in public indoor spaces it is now optional when outdoors.   Abu Dhabi Emirate has made it mandatory for residents aged 16 years and above and international tourists to have a âgreen passâ on the âAlHosnâ app in order to access public places. A green pass is acquired and maintained by full vaccination and regular negative PCR tests.   https://archive.ph/xGvVX#selection-1075.0-1075.274

Travellers entering the country must show a negative negative COVID-19 PCR test 72 hours prior entering the country; and will be tested up arrival.  "All passengers over the age of 11 leaving or entering Djibouti, including those who have been vaccinated, must show a negative result from a COVID-19 PCR test taken within 72 hours of boarding any flight bound for Djibouti and not more than 120 hours prior to their arrival at Ambouli International Airport (JIB). All travelers entering the country will also be tested for COVID-19 upon arrival and must wait at the port of entry until the results become available."    https://web.archive.org/web/20220216120454/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/01/djibouti-authorities-maintaining-covid-19-related-domestic-and-international-travel-restrictions-as-of-jan-17-update-23

Mask Mandate Canceled, Except in Places with High Risk of Infection    In view of the decrease in the morbidity of the Covid-19, the mask mandate in closed places will be abolished, except in places with high infection potential:    Medical centers  Clinics and HMO's  Organizations that provide emergency medical services  Nursing homes  International flights  Persons on their way to isolation  The decision will enter into effect this coming Saturday, April 23rd, 2022, at 20:00 subject to the approval of the Knesset Health Committee.    Source: https://archive.ph/spFWi

https://web.archive.org/web/20220321222606/https://jo.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/?_ga=2.98319197.393301103.1647901410-65558835.1647261475  Are PCR and/or antigen tests?available for U.S. citizens in Jordan??Yes  Are test results reliably available within one calendar day??Yes  The cost of COVID-19 testing in Jordan is 20 JD, and most labs accept cash or credit cards.? Individuals are responsible for the cost of the test.  Most labs in Jordan communicate the initial test results through PDF sent by text message.  However, some labs require individuals to pick up a hard copy of the results.?  Each lab will clarify the process of obtaining results after conducting the COVID-19 test.? The Ministry of Health provides?a list (in Arabic)?of 33 laboratories?in Jordan authorized to perform COVID-19 diagnostic testing.? Some of these labs include: Biolabs,?Alsultan?Laboratories, Precision Medical Laboratories, Med Laboratories, The Specialty Hospital, Mega Labs, Quest Labs, and Geno Labs.  Please check the Government of Jordanâs?COVID-19 website?for further details on testing, quarantine, and information.

https://web.archive.org/web/20220321222606/https://jo.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/?_ga=2.98319197.393301103.1647901410-65558835.1647261475  The Jordanian government recommends Jordanian citizens and residents use the Sanad.JO application to document vaccination status and recent PCR test results.  This is the only official means of verifying vaccination and PCR tests.  Jordanian citizens and residents may need to visit their nearest civil status office or SANAD station to activate their digital ID for use in the SANAD.JO application.

Pfizer-BioNTech, Astra Zeneca, Sinopharm, and Sputnik V  Individuals in Jordan may register to receive a vaccine at https://vaccine.jo/cvms/ (English and Arabic).  Both Jordanian citizens and non-Jordanian nationals (including U.S. citizens) are eligible to register for a vaccine in Jordan.

Effective May 1, normal pre-pandemic procedures apply and all COVID-19 health or travel restrictions will be lifted.  The Governmentâs April 27 announcement addresses the following:    Concerning masks:    Wearing masks is now optional in all indoor and outdoor places. Symptomatic individuals are encouraged to still wear a mask around others.  Masks are required for a period of 14 days for individuals infected with COVID-19 or who have come into close contact with positive cases.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220509145944/https://kw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Persons traveling to Kuwait do not need to take any form of test prior to arrival, regardless of vaccination status, and are no longer required to be fully immunized for entry into Kuwait. The Shlonik application will apply only as follow up on positive cases.  Travelers should still follow the Kuwaiti Governmentâs guidelines for obtaining relevant entry visas.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220509145944/https://kw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

PCR tests are widely and readily available.  Antigen tests are available locally, but difficult to find due to shortages.  Labs will generally return PCR test results within 24 hours.   The method of result notification varies by laboratory but is generally via text message or email.    If you have a medical emergency and are experiencing non-COVID symptoms, please call 112.  Please call the Ministry of Health at 151 or 2497-0967 if you are experiencing a fever, cough, or difficulty breathing.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220509145944/https://kw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Effective February 23, the mobile applications Mosafer and BilSalamah will cease to operate.  Effective May 1, the Shlonik application will only be used to follow up on positive cases.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220509145944/https://kw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Morocco requires proof of vaccination to enter most private and public establishments, including hotels, restaurants, cafes, gyms, hammams, grocery stores, and public modes of transportation. If vaccinated in Morocco, U.S. citizens should carry the vaccine pass (âpass vaccinalâ) issued by the Moroccan government and available at the Ministry of Health vaccination website. If vaccinated in the United States, we recommend U.S. citizens carry their white CDC card as proof of vaccination. Additionally, U.S. citizens vaccinated in the United States may be able to access the Vaccination Administration Management System (VAMS) within the United States to obtain a QR code. At this time, we cannot be certain what proof will be accepted by individual establishments.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222134405/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Mask-wearing is no longer obligatory in schools, however is still recommended. Social distancing and cohorting is encouraged.     Source: https://deputyprimeminister.gov.mt/en/health-promotion/covid-19/Documents/Education%20Guidance%20April%202022_25_4.pdf

Parties and weddings can resume as normal - vaccine certificates no longer required for entry into parties etc    Source; http://web.archive.org/web/20220504095049/https://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/national/116391/weddings_parties_back_to_normal_from_2_may_as_most_covid19_restrictions_are_lifted#.YnJMfXbP02w

Weddings, parties and all other social activities can resume as normal.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220504095049/https://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/national/116391/weddings_parties_back_to_normal_from_2_may_as_most_covid19_restrictions_are_lifted#.YnJMfXbP02w

PLF is no longer needed for travel to Malta. However, most travel rules have remained in place. Anyone arriving in Malta will still need to present either a vaccine certificate, negative PCR test or recovery certificate for entry. Red and dark red travel lists will also remain in place    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220504095049/https://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/national/116391/weddings_parties_back_to_normal_from_2_may_as_most_covid19_restrictions_are_lifted#.YnJMfXbP02w

As from 9th May, COVID-19 travel restrictions will be relaxed. Countries will no longer be classified as Red or Dark Red. This means that the travel ban for countries previously on the Dark Red list is no longer in force.     Travel to Malta now only requires any of the below:  - a recognised valid vaccine certificate   - a recognised valid COVID-19 recovery certificate   - a negative PCR test taken not more than 72 hrs before arrival   - a negative Rapid test taken not more than 24 hrs prior to arrival.     If one fails to present any one of these documents, they must undergo a 10-day mandatory quarantine, which can be reduced to 7 days following a negative test.     Children aged 6 or less are exempt from presenting any of these documents.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220513105703/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/malta-further-relaxes-its-covid-19-travel-restrictions/  http://web.archive.org/web/20220513110347/https://legislation.mt/eli/ln/2022/123/eng

Only those who test positive for COVID-19 will have to isolate. People who live with a COVID-19 patient no longer have to quarantine, unless they show symptoms of the virus. Primary contacts, even those unvaccinated, also no longer need to quarantine. Positive cases of COVID-19 must quarantine for 1 week, after which they can exit upon proof of a negative test, or remain in quarantine for 10 days total.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220504095049/https://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/national/116391/weddings_parties_back_to_normal_from_2_may_as_most_covid19_restrictions_are_lifted#.YnJMfXbP02w

Masks are no longer required in schools as from 13th April. Now that the mask requirement in schools is to be dropped, mandatory mask wearing will only be needed in shops and other public indoor places.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220420131455/https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/covid-self-testing-to-be-allowed-negative-pcr-test-for-red-list.945960

Masks are no longer mandatory in indoor public places such as shops, restaurants etc. Masks are only required on flights, inside hospitals, health clinics and care homes.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220504095049/https://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/national/116391/weddings_parties_back_to_normal_from_2_may_as_most_covid19_restrictions_are_lifted

In Gaza, there is a mandatory quarantine: 7 days for a negative COVID-19 test or 21 days with a positive COVID-19 test.    West Bank:   "- Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter? [Yes]  - Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry? [Yes]  - Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? [Yes] The Palestinian Authority requires all individuals who seek to enter the West Bank via the Allenby crossing to take a COVID -19 test within 72 hours."    Gaza:  "- Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter??[No]  - The de facto authority in Gaza stated that travel in and out of Gaza will only be permitted for urgent humanitarian cases through Erez and Rafah crossings and that those coming into Gaza will be required to take a COVID-19 test and quarantine for a mandatory period of seven days (with a negative COVID-19 test) or 21 days (with a positive COVID-19 test)."    US Embassy in Israel (which also covers the West Bank and Gaza), last updated 26 January 2022:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220505203051/https://il.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Vaccination continued in schools in the Gaza Strip in February and resumed in public schools in West Bank after a brief pause. WHO  provided  100,000  posters  to  encourage vaccination uptake in schools. Vaccination continues in public schools.    WHO Occupied Palestinian Territory Coronavirus disease 2021 (COVID-19) Situation Report  (Monthly issue: Feb 28 2022)  (Note: this is the most recent Situation Report as of May 5 2022)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220422015131/http://www.emro.who.int/opt/information-resources/covid-19-situation-reports.html

No particular measures for the elderly besides the booster shot.    WHO Occupied Palestinian Territory Coronavirus disease 2021 (COVID-19) Situation Report  (Monthly issue: Feb 28 2022)  (Note: this is the most recent Situation Report as of May 5 2022)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220422015131/http://www.emro.who.int/opt/information-resources/covid-19-situation-reports.html

Schools and kindergarten students will continue to be allowed back at a 100% capacity for all school levels.  All unvaccinated students and those who have not previously recovered from the virus must take a weekly rapid antigen test at home. Rapid antigen testing devices will be provided to public school students through their schools.Do not allow students on-site if they are showing symptoms of COVID-19, respiratory symptoms, or have been in close contact with someone who has confirmed or suspected COVID-19 in the last 14 days or have history of fever or feeling feverish the previous 24 hours.  Continue remote teaching where possible to support split or rotating schedules with continuous remote learning.   Make special considerations for vulnerable groups (e.g. online learning). Vulnerable staff members and students to remain at home and utilize distance learning.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220516195606/https://covid19.moph.gov.qa/EN/Precautions-for-lifting-restrictions/Educations-Health/Pages/New-Academic-Year.aspx

Capacity of staff in the workplace remains at 100%.?   Etheraz App to be downloaded by all employees, and visitors, and check that the status is green to allow  entry.   Limit the presence of maintenance teams inside offices during working hours and ensure their green Ehteraz status, wearing masks and compliance with all precautions. Meeting time should be limited as much possible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220516200952/https://covid19.moph.gov.qa/EN/Precautions-for-lifting-restrictions/Business-Leisure/Pages/Return-to-Work.aspx

There are currently no limits on the number of people at social gatherings. You will be asked to show your vaccinated status on the Ehteraz app to enter most locations. If you are unvaccinated, entry may be denied.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220516200320/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/qatar/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20220328212124/https://covid19.moph.gov.qa/EN/Precautions-for-lifting-restrictions/Gatherings/Pages/Social-Gatherings.aspx

Social gatherings are allowed with no restriction on capacity or maximum numbers?.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220328212124/https://covid19.moph.gov.qa/EN/Precautions-for-lifting-restrictions/Gatherings/Pages/Social-Gatherings.aspx

Metro services and public transport services to operate at full capacity?. Etheraz App to be downloaded by all staff, drivers, and passengers. Entry to stations or buses will only be allowed for those with a green health status. Masks must be worn by all staff, drivers and passengers to allow entry.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220328212124/https://covid19.moph.gov.qa/EN/Precautions-for-lifting-restrictions/Gatherings/Pages/Social-Gatherings.aspx
No stay at home mandates in place.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220404175050/https://covid19.moph.gov.qa/EN/Precautions-for-lifting-restrictions/Educations-Health/Pages/default.aspx

Travel in Yemen  Authorities across Yemen have introduced a range of measures. These include curfews, movement restrictions, closures of businesses and limitations on public and private gatherings. Implementation may vary and restrictions can change at short notice.    Some areas have designated quarantine camps. These can vary in both quality and access to medical provision.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220516183641/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/yemen/coronavirus#:~:text=Authorities%20across%20Yemen%20have%20introduced,areas%20have%20designated%20quarantine%20camps.

Transportation  Due to the ongoing conflict, Sana'a's El Rahaba International Airport (SAH) is only open to humanitarian and military flights and those with specific authorization. It is subject to closures on short notice.    Some land borders between Saudi Arabia and Yement are open    https://web.archive.org/web/20220516094656/https://crisis24.garda.com/insights-intelligence/intelligence/country-reports/yemen
